title: Joel McHale
text:
Joel Edward McHale (born November 20, 1971) is an American actor, comedian, writer, producer, and television host. He is best known for hosting "<a href="The%20Soup">The Soup</a>" (2004–2015) and his role as <a href="List%20of%20Community%20characters%23Jeff%20Winger">Jeff Winger</a> on the <a href="NBC">NBC</a> sitcom "<a href="Community%20%28TV%20series%29">Community</a>" (2009–2015). He has performed in the films "<a href="Open%20Season%202">Open Season 2</a>" (2008), ' (2011), and "<a href="Ted%20%28film%29">Ted</a>" (2012). He also starred in the short-lived <a href="CBS">CBS</a> sitcom "<a href="The%20Great%20Indoors%20%28TV%20series%29">The Great Indoors</a>" (2016–2017), hosts a reboot of "<a href="Card%20Sharks">Card Sharks</a>" (2019–present), and portrays the superhero <a href="Sylvester%20Pemberton">Sylvester Pemberton / Starman</a> on the show "<a href="Stargirl%20%28TV%20series%29">Stargirl</a>" (2020–present). In 2020, he hosted a special aftershow interviewing key subjects from the <a href="Netflix">Netflix</a> documentary series "<a href="Tiger%20King">Tiger King</a>". McHale voiced <a href="Johnny%20Cage">Johnny Cage</a> in the direct-to-video martial arts film ' (2020), whom he reprises in the sequel "" (2021). He also voices The Scientist in "<a href="Fortnite">Fortnite</a>" (2019–present).
Early life.
McHale was born in <a href="Rome">Rome</a> on November 20, 1971, the son of Jack McHale, who worked as the <a href="Dean%20of%20Students">Dean of Students</a> at <a href="Loyola%20University%20Chicago">Loyola University</a>'s Rome Center, and his wife Laurie. His father is American and is from <a href="Chicago">Chicago</a>, while his mother is Canadian and a native of <a href="Vancouver">Vancouver</a>. McHale is of Irish and Norwegian descent, and was raised Catholic. He grew up on <a href="Mercer%20Island%2C%20Washington">Mercer Island, Washington</a>, and briefly lived in <a href="Haddonfield%2C%20New%20Jersey">Haddonfield, New Jersey</a>, before returning to Mercer Island. He attended <a href="Mercer%20Island%20High%20School">Mercer Island High School</a>. He received a <a href="bachelor%27s%20degree">bachelor's degree</a> in history from the <a href="University%20of%20Washington">University of Washington</a> in 1995, and was briefly in the <a href="Theta%20Chi">Theta Chi</a> fraternity but left it because he "couldn't stand it."
McHale was recruited to be on the University of Washington's <a href="Rowing%20%28sport%29">rowing</a> team, but later joined its <a href="Washington%20Huskies%20football">football</a> team. Though most of his teammates received athletic scholarships, he was a <a href="Walk-on%20%28sports%29">walk-on</a> who played <a href="tight%20end">tight end</a> for two years on the scout team without appearing in an actual game. He was part of the "<a href="Almost%20Live%21">Almost Live!</a>" cast, a local <a href="sketch%20comedy">sketch comedy</a> television show produced by <a href="Seattle">Seattle</a>'s <a href="KING-TV">KING-TV</a>. From 1993 to 1997, he was a member of the <a href="improv%20comedy">improv comedy</a> group at <a href="Unexpected%20Productions">Unexpected Productions</a>, participating in "Theatersports!" at the Market Theater located in <a href="Pike%20Place%20Market">Pike Place Market</a> in downtown Seattle. He received an <a href="Master%20of%20Fine%20Arts">MFA</a> from the Professional Actors Training Program at the University of Washington.
Career.
Hosting.
In 2004, McHale began hosting "<a href="The%20Soup">The Soup</a>", a satirical weekly television show on the <a href="E%21">E!</a> television network. Throughout the show, he takes the audience through the oddities and ridiculous happenings of the week in television. He frequently appears as a co-host on "<a href="Loveline">Loveline</a>". He has been a judge on "<a href="Iron%20Chef%20America">Iron Chef America</a>". He was involved in the American version of the British TV show "<a href="The%20IT%20Crowd">The IT Crowd</a>". McHale made a guest appearance on the finale of "<a href="Last%20Comic%20Standing">Last Comic Standing</a>'s" sixth season, when he recapped the show's events in his typical format of jokes made popular on "The Soup". He also made an appearance as a guest judge on "<a href="RuPaul%27s%20Drag%20Race">RuPaul's Drag Race</a>" season 11, episode 4, """."
McHale was the host at the 2014 <a href="White%20House%20Correspondents%27%20Association">White House Correspondents' Association</a> annual dinner. He hosted the 2011 <a href="Independent%20Spirit%20Awards">Independent Spirit Awards</a> and the <a href="2015%20ESPY%20Awards">2015 ESPY Awards</a>. In 2016, he appeared as an occasional co-host alongside <a href="Kelly%20Ripa">Kelly Ripa</a> in the <a href="American%20Broadcasting%20Company">ABC</a> morning show "<a href="Live%20with%20Kelly%20and%20Ryan">Live with Kelly</a>". McHale hosted the <a href="43rd%20People%27s%20Choice%20Awards">43rd People's Choice Awards</a> on January 18, 2017 and the <a href="2017%20Webby%20Awards">2017 Webby Awards</a> on May 15, 2017.
In January 2018, it was announced that he would be receiving his own talk show on <a href="Netflix">Netflix</a> in February. "<a href="The%20Joel%20McHale%20Show%20with%20Joel%20McHale">The Joel McHale Show with Joel McHale</a>" combined celebrity guests, pre-taped sketches and video clips in a half-hour series that focused on pop culture and news from around the world. On August 17, 2018, it was announced that Netflix had canceled the show after 19 episodes, reportedly due to low viewership.
On April 8, 2019, TVLine reported that McHale would host a revival of the game show "<a href="Card%20Sharks">Card Sharks</a>" for <a href="American%20Broadcasting%20Company">ABC</a>.
McHale currently co-hosts "The Darkest Timeline" podcast with former "Community" co-star <a href="Ken%20Jeong">Ken Jeong</a>; the podcast was created in response to the ongoing <a href="COVID-19%20pandemic">COVID-19 pandemic</a>. Also in 2020, he hosted an after-show special of the <a href="Netflix">Netflix</a> documentary series "<a href="Tiger%20King">Tiger King</a>". With Jeong, they became the new hosts of <a href="Fox%20Broadcasting%20Company">Fox</a>'s <a href="New%20Year%27s%20Eve">New Year's Eve</a> special "<a href="Fox%20New%20Year%27s%20Eve%20specials">New Year's Eve Toast & Roast</a>". The second edition was canceled due to the quickly-rising cases of <a href="SARS-CoV-2%20Omicron%20variant">Omicron variant</a> in the <a href="COVID-19%20pandemic">COVID-19 pandemic</a>.
In 2021, McHale hosted "<a href="Crime%20Scene%20Kitchen">Crime Scene Kitchen</a>", also on 
Fox.
Acting.
After earning his master's degree in acting, McHale moved to Los Angeles and landed small roles in ', ', and "<a href="Will%20%26amp%3B%20Grace">Will & Grace</a>". He played a TV reporter in the biopic "<a href="Lords%20of%20Dogtown">Lords of Dogtown</a>". He guest-starred as a cast member on the <a href="NBC">NBC</a> improv comedy show "<a href="Thank%20God%20You%27re%20Here%20%28American%20TV%20series%29">Thank God You're Here</a>" during the pilot episode and had a guest role on an episode of "<a href="Pushing%20Daisies">Pushing Daisies</a>". McHale also appeared in "<a href="Spider-Man%202">Spider-Man 2</a>" in a small role as Mr. Jacks, a bank manager.
He has also had a long association with <a href="Circle%20X%20Theatre">Circle X Theatre</a>, where he has done several plays. McHale was a weekly guest on "<a href="The%20Adam%20Carolla%20Show%20%28radio%20program%29">The Adam Carolla Show</a>" and "<a href="Mickey%20and%20Amelia">Mickey and Amelia</a>", and occasional guest on "<a href="Opie%20and%20Anthony">Opie and Anthony</a>". He occasionally appeared on "<a href="Countdown%20with%20Keith%20Olbermann">Countdown with Keith Olbermann</a>" in a humor sequence closing the show.
McHale starred in the sitcom "<a href="Community%20%28TV%20series%29">Community</a>", which premiered in fall 2009, and continued to host "<a href="The%20Soup">The Soup</a>".
McHale made an appearance on the first episode of the fifth season of "<a href="Tosh.0">Tosh.0</a>". He played Rex in "<a href="Ted%20%28film%29">Ted</a>" (2012) and had a short guest stint on the FX show "<a href="Sons%20of%20Anarchy">Sons of Anarchy</a>". He played an <a href="New%20York%20City%20Police%20Department">NYPD</a> officer in the supernatural horror film "<a href="Deliver%20Us%20from%20Evil%20%282014%20film%29">Deliver Us from Evil</a>". McHale appeared in 3 episodes between the tenth and eleventh seasons of "<a href="The%20X-Files">The X-Files</a>" in 2016 and 2018, respectively.
McHale played the lead role in the <a href="CBS">CBS</a> sitcom "<a href="The%20Great%20Indoors%20%28TV%20series%29">The Great Indoors</a>", which began airing in the fall of 2016. The series was later cancelled on May 13, 2017 due to low ratings.
In 2018, McHale was cast in the recurring role of Chris on the second season of the <a href="Netflix">Netflix</a> horror-comedy series "<a href="Santa%20Clarita%20Diet">Santa Clarita Diet</a>".
In December 2018, it was announced that McHale was cast as <a href="Sylvester%20Pemberton">Sylvester Pemberton</a>, the Golden Age Starman in the <a href="DC%20Universe%20%28streaming%20service%29">DC Universe</a> and <a href="The%20CW">The CW</a> series "<a href="Stargirl%20%28TV%20series%29">Stargirl</a>". After sporadic appearances in its first two seasons, he was upgraded to series regular for the third.
McHale was a guest panelist in "<a href="The%20Masked%20Singer%20%28American%20TV%20series%29">The Masked Singer</a>". He was a guest panelist in episodes 8 and 9 of <a href="The%20Masked%20Singer%20%28American%20season%202%29">season 2</a>. He was also a guest panelist in episode 8 of <a href="The%20Masked%20Singer%20%28American%20season%203%29">season 3</a>. In <a href="The%20Masked%20Singer%20%28American%20season%204%29">season 4</a>, he was a guest panelist in episodes 3 and 4 where he did a performance of <a href="Robin%20Thicke">Robin Thicke</a>'s "<a href="Blurred%20Lines">Blurred Lines</a>" in the former episode as the "Robin" (depicted as a cut-out face of Robin Thicke). McHale was a guest panelist in the episode 3 of <a href="The%20Masked%20Singer%20%28American%20season%205%29">season 5</a>. Then, he was guest panelist in the episode 7 of <a href="The%20Masked%20Singer%20%28American%20season%206%29">season 6</a>.
Personal life.
McHale married Sarah Williams in July 1996. They live in the <a href="Hollywood%20Hills">Hollywood Hills</a> with their two sons, Isaac and Eddie. In a 2018 interview on <a href="Dax%20Shepard">Dax Shepard</a>'s podcast "<a href="Armchair%20Expert">Armchair Expert</a>", McHale revealed he was <a href="dyslexia">dyslexic</a>, having discovered this when his two sons were diagnosed.
McHale has said that he has an interest in watches. His interest started because of stylist Jose Camilo who got him to wear a Ritmo Mundo watch then buying a <a href="Bell%20%26amp%3B%20Ross">Bell & Ross</a> military watch. He now owns 12 watches altogether.
McHale is a fan of the <a href="Seattle%20Seahawks">Seattle Seahawks</a> football team and the <a href="Los%20Angeles%20Gladiators">Los Angeles Gladiators</a> esports team.
Politics and beliefs.
He attends a <a href="Presbyterianism">Presbyterian church</a> and has been supportive of the <a href="LGBT%20community">LGBT community</a>; while performing at the <a href="Durham%20Performing%20Arts%20Center">Durham Performing Arts Center</a>, he wore a handmade <a href="LGBT%20social%20movements">gay-rights</a> shirt, talked about the <a href="Public%20Facilities%20Privacy%20%26amp%3B%20Security%20Act">bathroom law</a> passed weeks prior, said he was donating all proceeds to the LGBTQ Center of Durham, and would not perform in the state again until the law was overturned.
McHale, along with several of his "Community" castmates, made a campaign video in support of Joe Biden in October 2020 entitled "Human Beings for Biden."
